INSTRUCTOR: The
inductive attenuates

demonstrates the
Laplacian nature

of magnetic fields
in free space,

the way that currents
distribute themselves

on the surfaces of
perfect conductors,

and the use of the
vector potential

in describing magnetic fields
in two dimensional systems.

Provided that the magnetic
flux density is in the xy plane

and depends only
on x and y, it can

be represented by one
component of the vector
potential, A sub-z.

In free space, the
vector potential
satisfies Laplace equation.

Separable solutions to
the Laplace's equation

that are periodic in
one direction decay
in a perpendicular direction.

Here, the direction
of periodicity

is x, while the
hyperbolic sine is

a combination of
exponentials representing
the decay in the y direction.

In this model, the
floor is the xy plane.

The altitude of the surface
is the vector potential.

Here's the direction
of periodicity.
Here's the direction of decay.

Because it represents a
solution to Laplace's equation,

every point on the surface
having a positive curvature

in the y direction must
have a negative curvature
in the x direction.

This is why periodicity
in one direction
implies decay in the other.

For this solution to
Laplace's equation,

3 of the rectangular boundaries
have a constant vector
potential.
The fourth is a sinusoid.

In our physical situation,
this fourth boundary

is elevated to a uniform
vector potential.

This can be represented
by a superposition
of these solutions.

To represent a uniform
vector potential,

solutions are added that
have a shorter wavelength.

By the nature of
Laplace's equation,

these have a more
rapid decay than

the fundamental in the
perpendicular y direction.

Here are the magnetic
flux lines represented
by the vector potential.

These are the boundaries where
the vector potential is 0.

This is the boundary
that is elevated
in its vector potential.

The surface of constant
vector potential

is one that sustains no normal
component of the magnetic flux
density.

It can be the surface
of a perfect conductor.

Here, these boundaries
of 0 vector potential

are perfect conductors,
carrying that surface

current necessary to terminate
the tangential magnetic field.

This boundary of
elevated vector potential
is also a perfect conductor.

The difference between
the vector potential

on this electrode
and on the wall

is the net magnetic
flux per unit length
passing inward through the gap.

Similarly, the difference
between the electrode vector

potential and the
wall potential here

is the net magnetic flux per
unit length passing outward.

The surface current passing
outward on the electrode

is returned in the side
wall and bottom wall.

In our model, lines
of constant altitude

are lines of constant
vector potential.

In two dimensions, lines
of constant A sub-z

are lines of magnetic
flux density.

So the wires are the lines
of magnetic flux density.

If you're familiar with using
a scalar potential to represent

an irritational
electric field, the role

played by the scalar
potential is being played here
by the vector potential.

Lambda is the flux per unit
length passing through the gaps

at the ends of
the top electrode.

In the electoral
quasi-static analog,

this flux is analogous
to the voltage

between the upper
electrode and the wall.
The analogy is intriguing.

It is the potentials
that are analogous.

In the electric
quasi-static situation,

the field lines are
perpendicular to the lines
of constant scalar potential.

Here, in our
magnetoquasistatic situation,

the lines of constant vector
potential are the field lines.

Although we may think of the
fields as two-dimensional,

their physical embodiment is
actually three-dimensional.
Here's the driving electrode.
Here are the sidewalls.

The current outward through
the driven electrode

is either returned
in the sidewalls

through connecting wires or
is induced in the bottom wall.

The current outward through
the driven electrode

is either returned
in the sidewalls

through connecting wires or
is induced in the bottom wall.

Over any cross section, the
fields are two dimensional.

The closer the bottom electrode
is to the driving electrode,

the more the current circulating
through the bottom electrode.

The current from this
20 kilohertz source

passes forward through
the upper electrode

and is returned in the
sidewalls through these shorts.

So that we can measure that
part of the current circulating

through the bottom
electrode, it's

insulated from the side
walls, but shorted to them
at each end.

Through this conductor, current
induced in the lower plate

can therefore return
in the sidewalls.

To complete the
loop, the lower plate

is also shortened to the
sidewalls at the far end.

Presumably, these shorts have
a sufficiently low impedance

that the lower plate remains at
essentially 0 vector potential.

That is, the shorts
are good enough

that little magnetic flux
leaks through the gaps

between the bottom
plate and the sidewalls.

We'll measure the
current induced

in the lower plate with
this current probe.

How much total
current is induced

in the bottom electrode
for a given voltage applied
to the upper one?
This is the actual apparatus.

Here are the sidewalls,
insulated from each other.
Here's the top plate.

Current from this source passes
forward through the upper plate

and is returned by the
shorts through the sidewalls.

Here are the connections
at the back end.

The source is
connected by the center

conductor of a coaxial cable
to the upper electrode here.

The driving current is
returned to the source

by these wires and the
coax shield conductor.

These leads are connected to
the top trace of our scope.

The top trace is
the driving voltage.

Here at the back,
the bottom plate
is shorted to the sidewalls.

It is also shorted at the
front, through these wires.

We measure the current
induced in this electrode
by means of this current probe.

The lower trace on the scope
represents the output current
from the probe.

It represents the net current
induced in the lower electrode.

Here's how the current
induced in the lower electrode

varies as the driving
electrode is lowered.

As the spacing is
increased, again,

with the driving voltage
essentially held fixed,
the induced current decreases.

As the driving electrode
approaches the lower electrode,
it increases again.

With the electrodes
this close, almost all

of the current in
the upper electrode

is imaged in the
lower electrode.

The current in the
lower electrode

is the integral of the
tangential magnetic field
intensity over its length.

By the nature of
Laplace's equation,

this field intensity
becomes weaker

as the distance between top and
bottom electrodes increases.

As the distance between
electrodes increases,

the fraction of the current that
returns in the lower electrode
is reduced.

The walls have a width W
and are separated by A.

We've been adjusting
the distance

B between the excitation
and detection plates.

Our modal theory tells us that
this output current I sub-0

has this dependence on the AC
excitation voltage amplitude V.

Here's the dependence on the
distance between excitation
and detection plates.

The normalizing current I is
proportional to the driving

voltage V and
inversely proportional
to the angular frequency omega.

To make a quantitative
comparison

between what we predict
and what we measure,

we need to compute the
normalizing current I.

The measured applied voltage
V is 8.2 millivolts peak.
The width W is 1/2 a meter.

And the frequency
is 20 kilohertz.

So in this case,
I is 0.53 amperes.

With B equal to A, the
measured current I sub-0
is 2.6 milliamps peak.

So the natural log of this
current normalized to I
is minus 5.I.

Graphically, this is
the predicted dependence

of output current on the
distance between upper
and lower plates.

The vertical axis
is the natural log

of the current in lower
electrode, normalized

to the current I,
which we just computed.

The horizontal axis
is the distance

between lower and upper
electrodes, normalized

to the distance
between the sidewalls.

The data point which
we've just taken

was for the electrode
spacing equal to the distance
between the sidewalls.
So our data point goes here.

Here are some other values
which we've measured.

The current I sub-0
in the lower electrode

does have the correct
variation, with spacing
between the electrodes.

However, it's displaced Downward
from the predicted curve

by essentially a constant
factor of 8 or 9.

The main reason for
this discrepancy

is the flux linked by
the wires used to provide
the return current pads.

The rate of change of this
flux makes an addition

to the measured
terminal voltage that

makes the normalization current
I larger than it should be.

To see this, we can
use a loop of wire

rather than the terminal
voltage to measure the flux

through the gap between
the upper electrode
and the left wall.

The loop passes along the outer
edge of the upper electrode

and is returned just outside
the adjacent conducting wall.

So arranged, it links little
extraneous flux at the ends.

Also, because it
will be connected

to the high impedance
of the scope,
it carries a negligible current.

And so the integral of the
electric field intensity

around the loop, which is
the voltage at the terminals,

does not have a part due to
the resistance of the loop.

The top trace is the
electrode driving voltage.

Here's the terminal
voltage of the loop.

With the spacing
between electrodes

equal to that between the
walls, the terminal voltage

of the flux loop is about
1.2 millivolts peak.

Under these same conditions,
the upper electrode terminal

voltage was 8.2 millivolts peak,
about a factor of 7 larger.

This data point and
others we've taken

using the flux loop, rather than
the upper electrode terminal

voltage, not only have
the predicted dependence

on electrode spacing,
but more nearly the

predicted absolute
magnitude as well.

The inductive attenuator
has illustrated

little Laplacian nature of
free space magnetoquasistatic
fields.

The magnetic field induced
by applying a voltage

to the upper electrode
decays essentially

exponentially into the
rectangular region, bounded

by the essentially perfectly
conducting sidewalls
and the bottom electrode.
